title: Post-Harvest Handling and Transport

requirements.question: Are harvested products promptly moved to designated collection or staging areas to minimize field exposure time?
Are staging areas for harvested product maintained to prevent contamination from soil, water, pests, or other sources?
Are transport vehicles and trailers inspected and cleaned before loading harvested product?
Is product protected during loading and transport to prevent physical damage and contamination?
Are temperature and time controls implemented during post-harvest handling to maintain product quality and safety?

mandatoryStatements: Harvested products must be promptly moved from harvest areas to designated collection or staging areas to minimize exposure to environmental contamination and temperature abuse.
Staging areas for harvested product must be designed and maintained to prevent contamination from soil, standing water, pests, equipment, or other sources.
Transport vehicles and trailers must be inspected for cleanliness and condition before loading product, with documented verification.
Product must be properly secured and protected during loading and transport to prevent physical damage, temperature abuse, and environmental contamination.
Appropriate temperature and time controls must be implemented based on product type to maintain quality and prevent microbial growth during post-harvest handling.
capaInject: Establish maximum holding times for product in field staging areas before movement to cooling or packing facilities.
Design staging areas with appropriate surfaces (paved, gravel, or compacted), drainage, and protection from environmental contamination sources.
Develop vehicle inspection checklists covering cleanliness, structural integrity, absence of odors or previous cargo residue, and suitability for food transport.
Implement loading procedures that minimize handling time, prevent product damage, ensure proper stacking, and protect from environmental exposure.
Define temperature monitoring requirements and holding time limits for different product types from harvest through transport to facility.
traceabilityInject: Maintain records of product movement from harvest to staging areas including time, lot/field ID, quantity, and responsible person.
Document staging area inspections including date, time, area condition, deficiencies found, and corrective actions before product placement.
Keep vehicle inspection records including date, vehicle/trailer ID, inspector, inspection results, cleaning performed, and approval for loading.
Track loading times, departure times, arrival times, and any delays during transport with vehicle ID and product lot traceability.
Log temperature monitoring data during post-harvest handling including time, location, product temperature, ambient conditions, and corrective actions if out of range.
micro_inject: Emphasize that extended holding times in warm conditions allow rapid multiplication of any bacteria present on product surfaces.
Ensure staging areas do not create new contamination risks through proximity to animal activity, standing water, or equipment contamination.
Implement protocols for vehicle inspection to prevent cross-contamination from previous cargo, soil, or other contamination sources.
Verify that loading and transport procedures minimize opportunities for pathogen introduction or growth through proper timing and temperature control.
Monitor post-harvest handling practices to ensure the food safety gains from good harvest practices are not compromised during subsequent handling.
